column4: Hello. How does Ubuntu make its packages. So far, I was under the impression that you just snapshot Sid every six months, make a few changes and release it, but someone I'm talking to is disputing that, claiming you make your own packages.
depends on the package.  they do that, but they also patch whatever's busted in sid or change version for those times when sid's instability means things arent working
and they add more things if they're wishlisted by users
bugfixes too, make their own set of defaults like having intel wifi work out of the box which debian makes you download separately....but the repos match pretty well
if you have something you want that isnt in ubuntu's repos and are using the latest ubuntu release, sid binaries usually work
Yeah, but compatibility with Debian is *very* limited
If that were the whole of the incompatibility problems, the software would still work
I use Sid, and I've had plenty of Ubuntu packages not work on me
*shrug* i just know that frets on fire works and a few other games one of my friends wanted worked fine too
Well, thanks for your help in settling the dispute (in my favour :))
Tell me, would Ubuntu accept any package that has copyrighted components without a license (for example, a game with artwork without a specified license)?
